title: 109_hr5552
content:
The "Securing America's Future Economy Commission Act" establishes a commission called the "Securing America's Future Economy Commission" with specified duties. The Commission will develop legislation to address long-term fiscal challenges in the US, including the imbalance between spending and revenues, increasing national savings for economic growth, foreign debt ownership implications, and improving the budget process. Legislation may include reforms to limit entitlement growth. The Commission will develop legislation to address long-term fiscal challenges in the US, including reforms to limit entitlement growth, strengthen safety net functions, make tax laws more efficient, incentivize private savings, and enforce spending and revenue targets. The Commission will develop alternative methods for estimating the cost of legislation to address flaws in the current method used by the Congressional Budget Office. The Commission will hold town hall style public hearings in each Federal reserve district to ensure broad public participation. During these hearings, the Commission will present issues, policies, and tradeoffs for public comments and suggestions. Additionally, the Commission will develop alternative methods for estimating the cost of legislation. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the President within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include a description of the Commission's activities, feedback from town hall style public hearings, findings on public preferences, long-term fiscal problems faced by the US, policy options to address these problems, and criteria for the legislative proposal. The Commission will submit a legislative proposal to Congress and the President within 60 days of the report submission, aiming to achieve generational equity, address public feedback, and meet the criteria set in the report. The proposal will include a long-term cost estimate and potentially an alternative cost estimate method. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP AND MEETINGS. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by various officials and 2 nonvoting members. Voting members are appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. Nonvoting members include the Comptroller General of the United States and the Director of the Congressional Budget Office. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by officials and 2 nonvoting members who advise and assist the Commission. Each appointing authority can only appoint 1 Member of Congress. Initial members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, with terms lasting for the life of the Commission. Vacancies must be filled within 30 days in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive compensation. The Commission consists of 15 voting members appointed by officials and 2 nonvoting members who advise and assist the Commission. Each appointing authority can only appoint 1 Member of Congress. Initial members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, with terms lasting for the life of the Commission. Vacancies must be filled within 30 days in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive compensation. Members of the Commission may not receive pay, allowances, or benefits, except for travel expenses. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the chairperson or a majority of its voting members, with six voting members constituting a quorum for meetings. SEC. 8. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission appoints a director who is responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. The director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission appoints a director responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. Staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The director may procure the services of experts and consultants as needed. The director may procure experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule under section 5316 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 9. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services upon request. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services upon request. Additionally, the Commission may enter into contracts, accept gifts, and donations to carry out its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its legislative proposal. The President and the Committee on the Budget have the option to submit alternative legislative proposals within the same timeframe. The Speaker of the House and Majority Leader of the Senate will introduce the legislation proposed by the Commission. In the House of Representatives, if a committee does not report the legislation within 60 days, it will be discharged, placed on the calendar, and a motion to proceed is highly privileged. Amendments are limited. Amendments to the legislation in the House of Representatives are limited, with specific permitted amendments including those proposed by the President, the Commission, or the House Committee on the Budget. In the House, amendments must have a long-term CBO cost estimate and cannot exceed the cost estimate of the legislative proposal. Multiple amendments are considered separately, with the one receiving a majority and the highest votes being adopted. In the Senate, similar rules apply. SEC. 14. LONG-TERM CBO COST ESTIMATE.

When requested, the Director of the Congressional Budget Office must provide a long-term cost estimate for proposed legislation or amendments. The estimate includes costs for the first fiscal year and the following 50 years, along with any additional future costs.
